free_text.Learning outcomes: The objectives of the course are to provide the students:[br/][li] the basics to understand the physical processes (and their dynamics) controlling the turbulent fluxes in the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL)[br/][li] the knowledge about how land surfaces influence the flow in the ABL[br/][li] the ability to work with turbulence data taken in the ABL using statistical tools[br/]
free_text.Content: The course will follow the book Introduction to Boundary-Layer Meteorology by Roland Stull (1989). [br/]The topics covered will be:[br/]1) Mean boundary layer characteristics[br/]Boundary-layer definition, turbulent transport, boundary layer depth and structure[br/]2) Statistical tools[br/]Turbulence and spectrum, Reynolds decomposition, kinematic fluxes, eddy fluxes[br/]3) Governing equations of turbulent flow[br/]Prognostic equations for mean variables, variances and turbulent fluxes[br/]4) Turbulent kinetic energy[br/]TKE budget, stability concepts, the Richardson number, the Obukhov length[br/]5) Boundary conditions and external forcings[br/]6) Time series analysis[br/]Structure function, FFT, energy spectrum.[br/]7) Similarity theory[br/]Scaling variables, stable boundary layers, convective boundary layers, the log wind profile[br/]8) Measurement and simulation techniques[br/]Field experiments, large-eddy simulations[br/]9) Convective mixed layer[br/]10) Stable boundary layer[br/]
